texts.text: There's a castle in Denmark haunted by a ghost. But not just any ghost! It's the ghost of the king himself!
The spirit stands at his son's bedside every night!
In time, it drove the poor lad mad...
They say he let his uncle take the throne in his place. The throne that his father left him, that was rightfully his!

texts.name: Regular Patron 1
texts.text: At least, that's the rumor I heard while I was in Denmark. What say you, Will? Intriguing, eh?!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That story again? Haven't you heard any better ones?

texts.name: Regular Patron 2
texts.text: And isn't the prince a bit spineless to be the son of a man who sticks around after death?

texts.name: Regular Patron 1
texts.text: Nah, that's how families turn out sometimes. Like when you get a worthless drunkard father to a truly upstanding lad...

texts.name: Regular Patron 1
texts.text: Why, just like you two here.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Who're you calling a drunkard, eh?!
My dad, who's sitting at the end of counter, snaps back.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: *Cough*! *Cough*!
It leads him to a coughing fit.

texts.name: Regular Patron 1
texts.text: Whoa there, old man. Don't die on us.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I got something in me throat, Will. Give me some ale, would ya?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, right! Have some water!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: The water's awful in this damn rat hole! Ain't that right, Ed?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: This is YOUR damn rat hole!

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Heh.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Like stupid father, like stupid son.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: You what?! Hey, Will! Give 'im a good smack right on the noggin! For the both of us! Come on!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Dad, they're patrons.
I notice Ed's cup is empty, so I pour him some more ale.
He flashes me a grin.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Hmm. It's true that Rob's story just now is lacking something.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: How about the one you told about the power struggle over in the Netherlands? The two would go together well.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Netherlands?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Hm?
Both Rob and Ed cock their heads in confusion.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You know, how the queen had an affair with the king's younger brother, and then they conspired to assassinate him.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I don't remember a story like that...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Well, you told it! You forgot?!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Right in the noggin! While he's distracted!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: We moved on, Dad. Pipe down already.
My father dejectedly hangs his head.
Rob laughs uproariously.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: If only it were true, but Rob's stories are always just some bunk he heard around town.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: When did I tell this story again?
Rob leans over to me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: About two years ago? You told it on a rainy day.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: How am I supposed to remember something I said over drinks two years ago?!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Say it like it is, Rob! Grab that no good son of mine and smack him on the noggin!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Is that what you did back when your eyes were good, Boss?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You bet! He whacked me so hard my memory's messed up. Now I remember everything I ever heard.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Jokes aside, I think that's a great ability. You should put it to use in other areas, not just remembering Rob's silly stories.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Yeah, you could memorize some recipes for food that's not crap.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ah, put a lid on it, would you?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: So, how do you link this Netherlands story with the Danish ghost story?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Well, what if the king learned of his wife's betrayal just before he died?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: What a rotten way to die! Unforgivable!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But her younger brother and the queen still manage to take the throne.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Shameless! And you call yourself my son?! I didn't raise you like this!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Boss, we're not talking about Will here. Keep it quiet, would ya?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: The young prince suspects nothing, until one day, his father's ghost appears to him.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: The ghost entreats the boy to take revenge on his own mother... and that's how you line them up.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: It does sound quite interesting.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: So what does the prince do after that?!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Dunno.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Why not?!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I just came up with it now.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Revenge against his mother who conspired to kill his father and put her lover on the throne. This story sounds violent indeed.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Heh, nothing that we don't see all the time in this rotten world. Nothing unheard of to you especially, eh, Ed?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: ...Yes, quite.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Oh, right. You work at a theater, don't you?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Yes. The popular plays are always filled with bloodshed and violence.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Gotta wonder if it's the writers or the public asking for that kind of story.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: A mix of both, I'd say. But it keeps the seats full, and the scones sell quite well.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: That's Tenbridge's most popular theater for you.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: But I'm certain you can write something good, Will. Why, I wouldn't put it past you to beat some of the scripts we get at the Lily Theater.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Aye! And I'll do my part by bringing you more great stories!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Why don't you focus on your real job instead?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: It's the last time I sell to you, ya bastard! Especially since you turn right around and sell them as-is!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm particular about dish presentation, I'll have you know.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: You just throw slices on a plate! Now I'm never selling to you again, and that's that!

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Without the pickled herring, all we'll have to go with the drinks will be potatoes.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: We have soup too.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: No one wants soup with their booze! It all just sloshes around in your gut! Why is soup the only warm thing on this damn menu?!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Because that's all I can make.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: How many years have you been doing this?! It's your damn pub, do something about it!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's my dad's, actually.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Though I'm not much more than part of the furniture by now.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: You could afford to be as quiet as the rest of the tables then, boss.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Agreed.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Give me a drink if you want me to shut up!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Is that a threat?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: What's worse, there's no pretty ladies to look at. Ain't that right? What's even keeping us here?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Well, Will is quite the looker. I always enjoy having him around.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Say, my lad. Have you ever thought about crossdressing? You have a pretty cute face.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Your voice is high enough too.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Yeah, why were you born a boy? I would've preferred a daughter, I would.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I see the drinks are kicking in, eh?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: It's settled, then! I'll get a costume from the Spencer troupe next time I visit! It'll fit you, I'm sure!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: They get no customers, so I bet they'll be glad to give you a pretty dress!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No way! We could hire a real girl if you lot would contribute more! Come on, drink! Eat! Stuff your faces, you swine!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Oi, boss! Your boy's callin' his customers swine. Don't you think he needs a whipping?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Give him a whack on the noggin for me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Bunch of violent pigs, the lot of you!

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I'd say this sense of camaraderie is something you can only get from a good bartender.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Want me to pay up that bad? Well, let's see how you like this! Fetch the cups, lad! The first one to fall off his chair loses!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Bring it on!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Ey! Let me in on the fun too!
The pub is full of familiar faces tonight.
How many years has it been since I started manning the counter myself?
Thanks to the friendly regulars, I managed to get used to serving people, despite my initial lack of aptitude.
We don't get that many customers, so I manage on my own.
That's the reason our menu is so limited.
But the complaining from the regulars is part of the fun.
Another day's work over.
My dad is at his usual seat at the end of the counter, slumped face down over the bar.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Oi, Will.
Just as I'm about to lock up for the night, I'm approached by Rob, one of the regulars who has stuck around until the wee hours.
Whenever he stays until closing time, I know exactly what he's after.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What is it? We're closed, all right?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: No, no more drinks for me. I want you to work your magic again.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Again? You're that short of hands? Surely you have your pick here in Tenbridge.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I could fill the Queen's castle with people who want to write. But I can count the number of writers who can please an audience with one hand.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Hah, that so.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: It can be comedy, tragedy, whatever you like.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I don't mind writing something, but it's gonna eat into my prep time tomorrow. You okay with soup and potatoes to complement your ale tomorrow?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Don't you worry. Your food sucks whether you prepare it in advance or not.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Oh, stuff it!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: The point is, focus on what you're good at.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: If only I were good at it!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Well, you're better at writing than cooking, at least.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I'll increase the pay from last time, okay? Sound good?
I look back at the counter.
My dad's dozing off.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Give me an advance and I'll start tonight.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: That's more like it! By the way, I'm told they want to start rehearsing this weekend.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That only gives me two days!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Hahahah!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: This isn't funny! That's even less time than the last time!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Aw, come on. How about you use that story from today? The one about the Danish ghost.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Yeah, make something out of that idea. I wanna see how it turns out.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I can't write a full tragedy in two days.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: How about a comedy, then?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: How am I supposed to write a comedy out of a man killing his mother after she killed his father?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: My lad, I am a firm believer that limits are made to be overcome.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What about the physical limits?! I can't just close up shop!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: You can do it! I believe in you! Forgo sleep for a couple days, and you'll be golden!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You say that after making me stay up all night drinking with you?!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Here's your advance! That's half the money! See you later, lad!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ah! Hey! You lousyâ€”!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Two days, huh?
I scratch the back of my head with one hand while I open the other.
The coins make a satisfying clink as they settle.
I stare at the three coins for a moment before putting them on the table.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Guess I gotta write then, huh.
I turn to my collapsed father and pat him on the back.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: We're done for today, Dad. You can go sleep upstairs.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Nh? Ah, my boy. Sorry, I dozed off.
I hand him his cane, take his hand to help him up, and we head to the stairs.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Rob stayed till late tonight. I'll handle the prep for tomorrow.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: He asked you to write another play?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Guess you inherited that talent from me. Sorry about that.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I don't think I've seen you write a word in my life.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: But I always thought I might write some day. Why, I do even now.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You won't, don't worry.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Tsk! Look at you, getting a big head just because you can string some words together!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's an honor to be able to write a script for a Tenbridge Troupe. I'm doing it because I like writing. I'll make sure it doesn't hurt the pub.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Nah, it's your pub now. Do whatever you like with it.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You're the owner.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I'm just a blind old drunkard now.
There's nowhere in this place that I need to guide my father to.
He knows this pub like the back of his hand.
So long as I put the seats back where they belong after the patrons are gone, my dad can find his way around with his cane no problem.
It took him a while to get used to losing his sight, but never underestimate how adaptable we humans can be.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I'll hit the hay, son.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Sleep well.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Good night. Don't stay up too late.
He slowly climbs the stairs.
I spread today's profits on the counter.
Another month in the red...
Even with the advance I got from Rob just now, it's not enough.
All this money will go right back into opening the shop tomorrow.
I sigh and brush my bangs off my forehead.
I'm seriously considering crossdressing if it'll bring more customers.
I can't even give my father a proper meal with this.
I let out another huge sigh in the empty pub.
No, this is no time to feel sorry for myself.
We can't live unless I earn money.
I get up and use the leftovers behind the counter to dish out supper for myself and breakfast for Dad while thinking about the script in my head.
There's just no time.
Do I use something I already wrote? Or slap something together out of half-formed ideas?
It'll have to be one or the other.
I think back on the stories I've heard during my time here.
All kinds of people from different backgrounds visit our pub.
This small room is like a vast library.
I think back on tales I've heard.
Shocking stories. Pathetic stories. Heart-wrenching stories.
All kinds of stories.
I put my father's breakfast in a pot for tomorrow and grab my own bowl of supper.
Then I blow out the lamps and head upstairs.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: The King of Denmark, huh?
I sit at my desk and stare intently at the quill.
My mind keeps coming back to that story Rob told today.
Ghosts, assassinations, parricide...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No way I can pull all those threads together in time.
I do think it would make a good story.
But I just can't put it together in two days.
I take a parchment from the shelf and look through some of my unfinished writing.
I can't be too picky now.
I have no money, therefore I must write.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Rehearsal in two days, huh?
Yet I have no time either.
First, I need to decide what to write.
Rereading some of my unfinished scripts, I remember the settings in which I heard each of the stories.
Wars between England and France, infighting between three princesses, a political play about ancient Rome...
Tenbridge is a hub for merchants who travel all around the continent.
Truly, I feel blessed to be in a place where so many stories converge.
One of them catches my eye in particular.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Oh, I'd forgotten about this one.
I search through my memory.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I got this one from Rob. He's really all about those rumors, eh?
Two women and two men.
A tale of foolish youths in love.
He said that he heard it in Italy, if I remember correctly.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: This could work, actually.
The concept is attention-grabbing and the story is clear-cut.
It'll be simple to write the kind of comedic scenes people would expect from reading the summary.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: All right. Let's go with this.
I turn back to my desk and pick up the quill.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Haah...
I trudge down the stairs, my steps a little unsteady after working all night.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Morning.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Morning, Son.
I find my dad peeling potatoes in his usual spot.
This is one of the few tasks that he's still able to do since he lost his sight.
Moving behind the counter, I see the meal I prepared last night still untouched.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You're not eating?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I could go for a drink.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Don't be grumpy now.
He lets out a throaty laugh.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You can rest. There's a gathering today, so there's no need to tire yourself out.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Don't worry. All I do is sit around and be a nuisance when the patrons come.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You make double the racket than all our patrons combined.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: That's just how I pass the time. Don't you worry.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Yeah, I could go for a drink.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You know I can't let you drink. Don't be stubborn.
His smile turns bitter as he continues peeling.
Now that I think about it, when was the last time I saw him eat anything?
It must have been about four days ago.
He nibbles on apples, and munches on nuts from time to time, but it's been that long since I saw him have a proper meal.
It was when I was restocking our ale supplies, if I remember correctly.
I glance at him again.
He's looking a little worse for wear every morning.

texts.name: Townsfolk
texts.text: Public execution! At the fountain square!
We hear someone shouting outside.
With it comes the hullabaloo of people moving in one direction and shouting.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Catholic hunting, eh?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Looks like it.
I stare at the door for a moment then turn to him.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Should we go?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: No...

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Not like I can see it with my own two eyes.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: All right.
Ever since Queen Elizabeth's coronation, the persecution of Catholics has intensified.
Being or even housing a believer is grounds for execution.
After pulling on the limbs of those poor souls until their tendons snap, they are exposed naked in front of all, and their intestines gutted to make a display out of them.
After that their head is severed from their bodies and put on a stake to adorn the castle for several days.
It has become something of a source of entertainment among the common folk.
This country has lost its freedom of creed.
I'm repulsed every time I see a portrait of the queen as I go about the city.
I wish she were made to experience the same pain and humiliation that is being inflicted upon others under her rule.
We stay there in silence, the pile of peeled potatoes growing larger.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: So, what are your plans for today?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Same as always.
I answer with a nod.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Will.
I look up at him.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Sorry, I need to go upstairs for a bit.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: All right.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'll come with you.
I slowly climb up the stairs after him.
We enter the largest room of the house, and my dad sits at one of the tables in the middle of it.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You're praying, right?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Yeah.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: All right.
I turn over a small painting on the wall, showing the image of the crucifix on the back.
This cross is a symbol of the Catholic faith.
If this idol were to be found, we'd be subject to capital punishment as well.
And yet, I somehow feel closer to God with such things around.
A person's faith cannot be fettered.
That was my father's steadfast belief when he set up this room as a secret meeting place for believers.
This is another facet of the pub we run together.
I walk behind my kneeling father and cross myself.
Then I clasp my hands together and join him in silent prayer.
We humans are weak.
We need something to support our fallible hearts, to draw strength from in hopeless times.
After a while, I open my eyes.
My father is still kneeling in front of me.
After staring at his back for a moment, I leave the room.
I go back downstairs and continue peeling potatoes.
The hustle and bustle outside doesn't abate.
I keep working, trying to put the horrific event going on outside out of my mind.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Hey.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Hey there.
We exchange knowing glances, and I nod.
If I'm familiar with someone, I don't need to ask for the password.
There's are just under ten people who regularly attend these gatherings.
We rarely get new faces.
With the persecution going on, it's no wonder.
Public executions have become a new source of entertainment for the people.
After Rob, a few more familiar faces come in and go upstairs.
All of them wear grim expressions.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Will.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Hey, Ed.
Ed smiles at me.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Is everyone inside?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah.
His expression softens a little.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Would you like to join us today?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: There'll be no one to keep officers from snooping around if I'm up there too.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: They're all manning their spectacle over at the square.
I look down at the potatoes.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Let us all pray together. If those that are left behind don't pray with all their hearts...

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: ...those suffering in the square won't find peace with the Lord.
He stares at me, conviction steeling his words.
I can see the fire of dissent in his eyes. A quiet, strong glow that yields not to the times we're living in.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: All right, Father.
I put the knife down and wash my hands.
Ed smiles kindly and goes upstairs.
I follow after him.
When I enter the room, Ed walks up to the front.
Less than ten believers are gathered around Rob and my dad.
Ed stands in front of everyone.
All turn their attention to him.
Everyone looks as grave as a tomb.
It's only natural, of course.
Believers just like us have been executed for simply offering prayers while trying to escape Queen Elizabeth's persecution.
Hiding believers, not to mention a priest, is a crime punishable by death.
I don't know under what charges today's execution is being carried out.
But I'm certain they couldn't have committed anything so atrocious as to warrant being slaughtered in front of a rabid crowd.
I'm sure everyone else here thinks the same.
Ed surveys the group.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: The times are changing, and the world along with it.
He starts talking in a clear, measured tone.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: We may needs to hide our faith and sneak like thieves in the night, but a pastor never leaves his flock unattended. I am certain that, in time, a wise, fair ruler who understands the holy spirit will come to guide men and women alike.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: We must weather this storm.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Our steadfast perseverance will surely pave the way for those who come after us.
Ed's expression is calm, but his voice has a strength of will that makes the air in the room shiver.
His poise makes me realize that I could never make it as a priest.
I can't forgive this oppression.
I can't smile in the face of adversity like he does.
I want to see those who do these awful things pay.
...Maybe this is why everyone flocks to Ed.
His smile is our salvation in these trying times. It's a rock in the desert.
Ed places his hand atop the Bible and closes his eyes in prayer.
Everyone else does the same.
When Ed's sermon ends, we all leave the little hall.
We always go down to the pub afterwards to eat together.
Everyone looks cheerier now.
I'm sure the pub's atmosphere is helping to ease their minds.
This is exactly what the pub is for.
I love to stand behind the counter and watch everyone having a good time.
Even my dad is smiling.
The good times keep rolling, and one by one, people leave a little happier than they came.
In the end it's only Rob, Ed, Dad, and me.
The usual suspects.
The ale keeps flowing, and so does time.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I'm glad we have this place.
Rob mutters, taking a sip from his cup.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: If it weren't for this here pub, I'm sure I would have lost it long ago.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Being able to recognize your own weakness is the first step to forgiving weakness in others.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Perhaps faith itself was born out of our weakness.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Maybe, yeah.
Rob stares at the ale swaying inside his cup for a while, then takes the last swig.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Why, perhaps ale was born because of our weakness as well.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: In other words, it would be morally right to let your old man wet his lips in these trying times.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I feel like that's a bit of a leap of logic.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Oh, you think so?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, you old coot. How many times do I need to tell you to give it a rest?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Just one cup, please!

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: One becomes two, which in turn becomes three. Then you lose count.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: He who has eyes, let them see.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Ah, shut it! You sticks in the mud!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Who's the parent and who's the child here?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Oi, lad. How's the script coming along?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Well enough. I pulled out one of my rough drafts and I'm fixing it up.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Huh? Not using the story of the king from yesterday?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I can't get that done in two days.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: What is this story you're working on about then?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm basing it on a story Rob supposedly heard in Italy.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Italy? Me? When did I tell this story, lad?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: About four years ago.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: So this was when I wasn't in Tenbridge, then.
As a priest, he moves towns regularly.
Staying in one place for too long attracts the attention of the Queen's men.
If memory serves right, he should be setting out for a new city this summer.
We'll miss him, but there are more Catholics all over the country who need the encouraging message of a priest like him.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Four years, eh? So around the time you started manning the counter.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Can't say I remember. What story was that?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You know, the one about the letter. The one that got switched.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: A letter? Ah!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Yes! I remember now! Hahah, that was a good one, all right!

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I think I've had enough suspense for an evening. What story is this?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Let me tell you. It was a bit of hearsay that reached my ears over in Italy.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: A rumor, you mean.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Rob has a lot of those.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: So it's a story about this beautiful lass and this handsome lad in Rome. They exchanged letters for over a year.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Mhm.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: They spun poems and vows of love through the written word, fanning the flames of their love despite not having ever heard one another's voice.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: But they had seen each other, I assume?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Not quite. Their beauty was famed throughout the city. That's not the whole story, though.
Rob leans forward.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Their letters were always delivered by a certain boy. This boy delivered their letters to another party.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Oh?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: To another pair of lovebirds that shared the same name as them.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: In other words, two different men were exchanging letters with two different women.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: For a whole year?!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Pretty intriguing, isn't it?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: It all started when the boy delivered the first letter from the man to the wrong lass. But by the time he noticed, it was too late. The woman was beside herself with joy after reading the letter.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: And that's how they began to exchange letters with the wrong person. Oh, how easy it would have been to correct his mistake early on.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: But the boy racked his brains to find a way to make things work. And thus, he delivered the woman's letters to another party as well.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Oho.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Any town is full of men looking to bag themselves such a beauty, so the boy found a man with the same name as the original handsome lad, and delivered the letter.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: So a new exchange was created.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: He figured they'd stop soon enough, and that'd be it. He could never have predicted that all four of them would develop such a passion for poems and exchanging vows of love.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: An unwilling cupid, if you will.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Quite.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: So they're sharing correspondence with the wrong person for over a year... We're talking about a comedy, I assume.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's a tragedy, in a sense.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: The man the boy found was married.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: The plot thickens!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: This is no good. No good at all.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: With the roaring flames of love burning in his heart, the man decides to abandon his family and elope with this girl!

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: And then?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: And then...

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Go on.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: That's all I heard.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: What?!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Why?!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Because it was hearsay, my good men.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: The punchline in Rob's stories shines for its absence more often than not.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Wonder what happened to them in the end.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Remember this is all rumor. It's already up for debate whether any of this really happened.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Don't break the mystique, would you?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: It's true that I heard about it, that I assure you!

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: No one's doubting you on that front.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: So, what are you doing with this story?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: The crux of this story is the burning passion these people develop for the wrong person, right?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: One of them even abandons his family to try and live out this fantasy of pure love.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I guess any man could relate.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, a lot of people can relate to dreaming of a better life. It's a simple, universal concept.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: But this a play, isn't it?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Sounds boring if the whole thing is just a back and forth between letters.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Even if it takes a year for love to develop in real life, you only need three lines in a play.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Just three?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: With the help of magic, for example.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I see.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: So, what, the kid uses magic or something?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What if the little miscreant who mixed up the letters was a fairy instead?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: A fairy, you say?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You have a pair of women and men.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And they end up falling for the wrong person thanks to the mischief of a little fairy.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Huh, that doesn't sound half bad.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm framing it as a comedy to make people laugh and leave the theater with a smile on their faces.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And I'm planning for a happy end where, after the whole mess, everyone ends up with the right person.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: So this boy turned fairy assumes the role of a jester, then.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Sounds good! You're a genius, lad!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I quite like writing, and I actually enjoy coming up with stories.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But you're always hurrying me!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Still, it looks like you won't disappoint this time either!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm not having an easy time, you know?!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I gotta think about what to do with that fairy angle and there aren't enough characters to fill in the time.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I'd say you're doing remarkably well. No playwright in the Lily Theater could work as fast as you.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Speaking of the Lily Theater playwrights...

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Notably, Christopher Marlowe, yes.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: That'd be Tenbridge's most popular playwright, yeah?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: But Will is faster, and his stories strike me as having more depth.
Ed turns to me.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: You can win, my boy.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You think so?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Set your sights high! All right! I have just the thing to put some pep in your step!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Eheheh, it'll knock your socks right off.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Mm?
Rob rummages in his bag and produces a bit of something deep red in color.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Jerky?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Not just any jerky, my lad.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Is that... venison?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: You bet!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Oooh!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That's really fancy, isn't it?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Fancy? Lad, that's a luxury.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Get yerself a deer and sell all the meat off its bones, and I reckon you'd make three month's worth of the pub's earnings in one day.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Three months for just one deer? It's that expensive?
I knew it was a luxury food, but goodness.
Three months? That's just ludicrous.
...Where can I even find deer?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Heheh, a gift from your most valued customers.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Whoa, really?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: That Spencer guy keeps deer the way one would dogs.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Oh, I see now.
He keeps those expensive animals as pets?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I'm just sharing what I was so graciously given.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Money certainly holds a different value to those nobles.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Let's eat it together. I don't feel like eating alone today.
His tone sinks like a rock in water.
Perhaps he's remembering the ghastly sight of those in the square today.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Gotta eat to live, eh? Here, Will.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Thanks.
I tear off a bite of the jerky.
Ed follows suit, as does Rob.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Have some, Boss. It's venison. None of us see this often.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I've never had it before.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Go right ahead.
Ed speaks around a mouthful.
I break off a bit of the meat and put it on my dad's palm.
He carefully picks it up between two fingers and slowly brings it to his mouth.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Well, don't mind if I do.
After a bit of chewing, he opens his unseeing eyes wide.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Hmm, this is rather good.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I hear it's good for you. Eat up, old man. You've been getting thinner, and don't think I haven't noticed.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: You've been telling them, Will? Don't burden the customers with stuff like that.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: If you eat, I won't have to. No more ale for you.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Like hell! I'll drink in my grave!
It's late at night, and Ed is the first to leave.
Right after that, Rob gets up from his seat as well.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Well, Bard. I leave the script writing to you. Have it to me by tomorrow, as we agreed.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, got it.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I'm looking forward to reading it meself.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Say, Rob.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Do you think I could get more work writing plays?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: ...Money troubles?
I nod.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Hmm... You know it's no jest when I say that there's people eternally lined up in front of the theater in the hopes of becoming playwrights.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: The deadlines I give you are always so tight because they don't come knocking on my door unless some kind of problem popped up.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, I know.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I suppose you could get picked up as a regular playwright in some theater if you keep doing good work, but you can't just abandon your main job here.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: It's a hard selI, I must admit. They won't take scripts from a peddler like me unless it's some kind of emergency.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I see...

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Sorry, my lad. I'll make up for it by giving you good business.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Thanks, Rob.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I know you're having it rough, lad.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Not so much. I have loyal clients that eat the crap I put on their plates, and I get to hear lots of stories.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm living a good life.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: That so? Heheh. I'll come buy out that crappy food so you guys don't go under.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You're gonna have a huge pot belly by the end.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Hahah... Sorry for not being able to help. I could be your patron if only I was one of those nobles.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Don't apologize, you do a lot for us.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: It's been a long day.
Rob looks up at the night sky out the window.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Sure has.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I wonder how long this will keep going on.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: There's no evil that lasts a hundred years, nor a body that can endure it.
He turns back to me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That's something Ed once told me.
He laughs heartily.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Everyone's a poet now. I see how it is.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: All the world's a stage.
He nods in response.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Make sure you put some of that literary fire in the script, will you?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I'm counting on you, Bard.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No pressure or anything...
After staying up all night two days in a row, I manage to get the script in a presentable shape by the second morning.
I notice Dad hasn't touched his meal today either.
I go up to my room in the afternoon to catch some shut-eye before work.
Rob shows up to pick up the script just before it's time to open the pub, a little before sundown.
I'm not completely happy with it, but it's good enough for the time I was given.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Thanks, lad! You're my savior!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: To be honest, there are a few parts that are still a bit rough. I don't mind if they feel like touching things up during rehearsal.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: No matter, lad. Mind if I give you the rest of the money when I get it from Spencer?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Sure. Thanks.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Huh? Where's the Boss?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Still in bed. He should be getting up soon.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Still not eating?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Doesn't seem like it. He hasn't eaten a thing today.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: That's worrying.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: He doesn't listen to me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Lately, I think he's trying to act like everything's all right for my sake.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: The man can put up a brave front even while blind, eh? That's some resilience.
It's been four years since his eyesight started worsening significantly.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: You got confidence in this thing?
Rob asks, lightly tapping the script.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's competent. The fairy character is well done, I think.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's a good role, so I bet it could be popular if the actor nails the part.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: That's what I like to hear. Thanks, my lad.
After a while, my father slowly comes down the stairs.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Rise and shine. Rob's here, Dad.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Oh, that you, Rob? Skipping out on work again?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: The first thing you do is slander me?! I'm turning your son's scripts into money so this place doesn't go out of business!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Want a drink? I bet you do. Come and get some ale in you.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I can't get drunk until I turn in this script!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Aw, don't be coy.
Feeling as he goes with his white cane, Dad heads for his usual seat at the end of the counter.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Son, how about pouring your father some ale to wet his whistle?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You know what the answer is.
He flashes an amused grin in my general direction.
To be honest, he doesn't look well enough to drink.
He's just overcompensating with banter.
I put out the 'open' sign after Rob leaves.
Though it's not like there's a huge line of people waiting to enter.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: *Cough*
Dad coughs a little, and it sounds bad enough for me to raise an eyebrow.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Are you sure you're feeling well?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Yeah, same old.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Wanna eat something? I'll cook.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: It's fine. The jerky from yesterday was enough.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But you'll feel better if you eat something.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Is there anything in particular you want? We're good for this month, so I can go buy something.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Wait until the end of the month. You still have to get paid, right?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, but...

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Don't you worry. I don't move about a lot, so I don't need as much food.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: You've been working yourself to the bone these days. You should rest a bit. You gotta take care of yourself.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That's rich coming from you.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Hahah, touche.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'll close up shop early tonight then head to bed.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Good.
At night, Ed shows up after work.
He nurses his cup of ale and treats me to one as well.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I see Rob's not here.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah. I wanted to ask if the script was well received.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: It'll be fine. Your work speaks of human nature itself.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: The people want to see real stories about the struggles we all face.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: If that's the case, I have Rob to thank for feeding me rumors, and you for always asking the poignant questions.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: The rumors he definitely heard from people in countries he hasn't even been to, you mean?
I laugh in response.
Ed echoes it with his own laughter.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: You think he really hears them from other people?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: If he comes up with all those stories on his own, he's a bloody genius.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: You're the one actually writing them down, though. And no one but you would have the memory to recall so much from years past.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Hmm... You think so?
He nods firmly.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: You have talent. I've become able to spot such things after working at the Lily Theater for so long.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I've listened to what I've been assured are the best plays Tenbridge has to offer while preparing scones to sell to those in attendance.
He pauses for a moment then directs a broad smile at me.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: And I don't think your work has anything to envy in comparison.
Since he's a priest, Ed has to do a lot of odd jobs while in hiding.
From what I gather, the theater he works at is always at capacity.
And the playwright writing those scripts must be...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Christopher Marlowe, yeah?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Yes.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Isn't it dangerous to work at the theater? You've been there for a long while now.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And there are always so many people around.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: No better place to hide a tree than the forest.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I suppose... But some people might start getting suspicious. It's best to err on the side of caution.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Thanks for the concern.
Ed smiles and nods.
Just as it's a crime to shelter Catholics, there is a reward for denouncing them to the authorities.
In a sense, the whole city is his enemy.
Many people will jump at shadows for the chance of getting rewarded, so it's important to not raise any kind of suspicion.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: By the way, what's the title?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Of the play, you mean?
Ed nods.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: A Midsummer Night's Dream.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: A story of the events of one night disappearing like a dream.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's a satirical comedy that I hope can touch people's hearts.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: A Midsummer Night's Dream, huh? It has a nice ring to it.
Ed murmurs, taking a swig of his ale.
I do the same.
I feel like something's not quite right here.
Dad's not heckling.
I turn my gaze to his seat at the end of the bar.
He's slumped face down across the counter.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Uh, sorry, give me a minute.
Realizing the situation, Ed smiles and nods.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Dad, go upstairs if you wanna sleep.
But when I put my hand on his shoulder to rouse him, I realize something's wrong.
He's shivering.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Dad?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: S-So cold... My head...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Are you in pain?! Dad?! Are you all right?!
Ed quickly notices something's wrong and approaches.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ed, Dad's...
He puts one hand to his forehead and the other over the nape of his neck.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: He's cold, could be hypothermia. Can you close the pub?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm on it.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Carry him upstairs, carefully. We need to warm his armpits and thighs. Prepare hot water.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Got it.
I take my father upstairs and do as Ed instructed.
Apparently, the way to deal with mild hypothermia is to warm the person up and get nutrients into them.
I gather from Ed's quick thinking that this isn't the first time he's dealt with something like this.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Thank you. I wouldn't have known what to do if you weren't here.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Think nothing of it. There are many who fall victim to the same condition wandering through the city at night.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Needless to say, alcohol is out of the question. It's a diuretic, and that's not what he needs in his condition. Give him warm water to drink.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Okay.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: It would be preferable if he got his appetite back.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, but he's not been eating at all.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Then we should contact an apothecary. I have an acquaintance we can call upon.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That'd be great, thank you.
I'm genuinely relieved for a moment, but then the implications of it dawn on me, and I feel my stomach turn into a piece of lead.
I don't have any money on me.
I haven't gotten the other half of my pay from Rob.
Perhaps noticing the gears turning in my head, Ed turns to me with a smile.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: No need to worry about money. I will foot the cost.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But I don't know when I'll be able to pay you back.
To be honest, even with the money Rob still has to give me, we can barely make ends meet.
This could quite literally push us into bankruptcy.
How much does an apothecary even charge for their services?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Then you can pay me when you become a successful playwright.
I give him a small, sheepish smile.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I don't expect to become a playwright anytime soon, if ever.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: You might very well make it. I believe in you.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Don't worry. You're not alone.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I feel so pathetic.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: No, you're an upstanding young man.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Thank you. I'm really sorry about all this.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: John has always been there for me. He's a brave soul.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: And you're so very much like him.
He puts on a reassuring smile for me.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I'll go call him. You stay by his side.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Thanks, Ed.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Please, think nothing of it. I always enjoy a good meal here.
I go upstairs and sit by my father's bedside.
He still looks to be in a really bad way.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: ...Sorry.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Mhm.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I'm so pathetic.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's not your fault.
I refresh the hot water, soak a cloth in it, and wrap it around his arm.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I know you have no appetite, but you need to eat something.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: This is happening because of malnutrition.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I know that, but nothing stays down the hatch these days.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: But I'm useless just prostrated on a bed like this.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That's right. All our patrons only come by to see you.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Hahah...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ed's fetching an apothecary. He says they can make medicine for you.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: An apothecary? No need! I can sleep this off, boy. Don't waste money like that.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's fine. I just sold a script.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: You didn't get paid a fortune for that, I'm sure. Use that for next month's payments.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's fine! Ed went to call them just for you. It can't hurt to have them examine you.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I suppose...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What is it?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I'm sorry, Son.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I told you, it's fine.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I don't think I'd need an apothecary if I had some ale.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Well you can't be feeling that bad if you're cracking jokes.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I feel like I could get a lot better with some ale.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No, it's a diuretic. You'd just lose more heat.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No tea for you either.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Even if you were to give me something that fancy, I doubt it'd suit my common palate.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Your palate seemed to get on with that venison all right.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Yeah, I suppose that's pretty expensive too, huh?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Try to get some sleep. Are you feeling cold?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Nah, I'm okay.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'll go tidy things up downstairs. I'll be back when Ed comes.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: All right.
I get up from the wooden chair and glance at him one last time before leaving the room.
I return to the pub and clean up the dish and cup I used to serve Ed.
What Rob said yesterday comes back to me.
That Spencer guy keeps deer like one would dogs.
Spencer, huh?
Harold Spencer.
The name has come up many times in my talks with Rob.
He said that the ones who wanted the script today were the Spencer troupe.
I wonder if we could make some kind of deal.
If just one of those deer found its way into my hands, I could slice it up, sell it off, and get my dad any food he wants.
I can't keep relying on Ed's good will forever.
I sigh, my shoulders slumping.
How are we supposed to see the light at the end of this tunnel?
My mind is miles away as I carry on tidying up the pub.
After a while, Ed shows up with the apothecary in tow.
All indicates that he's a Catholic as well.
He wouldn't be risking it coming here otherwise.
He examines my father, palpates him, and prepares a few days' worth of medicine for him.
It's to help raise his basal body temperature, apparently.
Thankfully, the amount Ed ends up paying the apothecary is a lot less than I imagined.
Perhaps it's because of Ed's good offices.
In any case, I think I could actually pay it back sooner rather than later.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Thank you for everything, Ed. Without you, I wouldn't have had a clue what to do.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Don't even mention it.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: When Rob comes with the payment for the script, I think I can pay you back.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I really mean it when I say you can pay whenever it's convenient for you.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I can't do that. Let me pay you. It's money I got from writing scripts, anyway, so you could say I'm already being successful.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Heh, touche.
He says, chuckling to himself.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Well, I suppose I'll accept your payment from that script.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, Rob should be here soon.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Have some ale, on the house. Let's drink and wait for him.
I hand Ed a cup and serve some for myself as well.
He raises his cup up to me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Thanks again.
I raise mine and clink it against his.
By the time the third bottle's empty, the sound of rain spattering against the roof is impossible to ignore.
Our eyes are drawn to the window.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Rob's not coming, eh?
As I mutter to myself, the front door opens.
He stands at the door, his shoulders wet and heaving.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Oh, hey there!
Rob smiles at me, but it looks awfully forced.
He's holding a bunched up parchment in his right hand that I imagined he tried to hide under his clothing.
It's the same script I gave him earlier.
I only notice that by the fact that it is not wet at all.
He takes a moment to recover his ragged breath.
He scratches the back of his head awkwardly.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Sorry, lad. I stuck around long as I could...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: They didn't take the script?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I can rewrite it if they had complaints.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: That's not the problem. He didn't even show up.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Why not?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: It seems like Spencer was attending a play today.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: A play?
In other words, he was out enjoying himself at the theater?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But didn't they set the deadline for today?!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I was under the same impression, yeah.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Did they forget about it?!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: No, uh, mm... Sorry. If for some reason they don't take the script in the end, I'll do something about your money.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: But I need to go to London tonight. I'm really sorry. I just need you to wait a little longer.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No, it's fine. I know it's not your fault. It's just that...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I really need the money.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Don't stress on my account, Will.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: What? Something happen?
He exchanges glances with Ed.
I nod in response.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: John came down with something.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: The boss?! Say it's not so!

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Malnutrition and hypothermia. His life is not in danger.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ed called in an apothecary and footed the cost.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Oh, for the love of..
Rob trails off, and an awkward silence hangs over the room.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Heh, I suppose we've seen better days.
I break the silence.
Rob lifts his gaze to my face.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Can I have the script?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Huh? What are you gonna do?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'll hand it over to Spencer myself. I'll wait for him to get back home.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: I can't just let you do that. I'm the middleman here.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: If it's so urgent, I'll pay on their behalf for the time being.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I can't do that to you.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: If I keep relying on you two for everything, I won't be able to live with myself.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'll feel more at ease actually doing something for myself for once. Please.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Well, you won't be able to enter the estate, so you'd have to wait outside.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: And the guy may not even show up until tomorrow.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's fine. It'll just mean no mashed potato on the menu tomorrow.
Rob stares at me with an anxious look on his face.
After a tense moment, he sighs and hands over the script.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Well, it is your script. If you want it back, then you'll have it back.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Half of it is mine, actually. The other half is already paid for.
I hold the parchment in my hand.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm sorry, but I think I need to close the pub for tonight.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Worry not, son.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Your pub, your rules.
I'm gripping the parchment so tightly that it's starting to wrinkle.
I didn't write this for fun.
I spun this story over two sleepless nights while taking care of the pub.
What the hell is going on?
My dad falls sick, and they don't even have the decency to take the script they asked for in the first place?
I couldn't make this up in one of my tragedies.
Far from letting up, the rain seems only to be increasing in intensity.
I roll up the manuscript and run through the rain in the direction Rob instructed me.
I enter the area where the nobles have their residences, and before long I find myself in front of the Spencer estate.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: This is the place?
It's a huge mansion.
How many pubs could I fit in here?
I wonder if this Spencer guy and his peers keep deer in all of these huge gardens.
I sit on one of the stone steps leading up to the mansion.
A thicket of trees in the opulent garden offers a slight reprieve from the biting rain.
Now all I can do is wait.
A thicket of trees in the opulent garden offers a slight reprieve from the biting rain.
But despite the bone-chilling cold, the rain is the last thing on my mind.
Rather, my thoughts are with the coming sunrise.
This is my third night in a row without sleep.
My head's starting to feel hazy with fatigue.
And what in the Lord's bones I am going to do after this?
Unable to find an answer, my thoughts go round and round in circles.
I take out the little flask of alcohol I brought to keep myself sharp and take a big swig of it.
The clear, viscous liquid lights up my throat.
It goes down to my stomach, where it settles in a hot, bitter pool.
So many emotions swirl about in my head.
I'm being deprived of my faith, seeing fellow believers put to the blade.
I'm tired of managing a dead end pub, unable to even properly feed my only remaining family.
All while others joyfully enjoy nights out at the theater and fatten deer up in their opulent gardens.
The people living here lead a much better life than we do.
I bet they enjoy lavish dinners a thousand times better than anything my dad has ever eaten.
Are they really so much more noble than us?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Is there a reason?
They must have leftovers.
Surely they have too much here?
Would it kill them to share some?
They're the ones who broke their promise.
I take another swig of my flask.
And the guy may not even show up until tomorrow.
Rob's words ring in my head.
Isn't that convenient for me?
I have to do what I can to make the best of a bad lot.
I don't have the luxury of choice.
If I do nothing, we'll simply starve to death by the wayside, our bodies to be picked at by the rats and the maggots.
I could steal some of what they don't need.
I bet they wouldn't notice if a single deer is missing.
Just one single deer.
It's not like it would ruin them, is it?
It wouldn't affect them in the slightest.
No one would even notice.
And I could feed my dad.
The pub could stay open.
Why, yes.
It wouldn't even be theft.
I'd simply be ever so slightly adjusting this unbalanced distribution of wealth.
Isn't that right?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...It is.
I put my flask away and get up.
Circling around the mansion, I come out into a clearing.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: This is it.
Dozens of deer pace about inside a fenced off area.
I feel like one of them makes eye contact with me.
It stares at me for a moment, ears twitching, and then it loses interest and goes back to grazing.
I smash my flask on the fence.
The broken bottle gleams ominously under the moonlight.
Then I take a good scan of the fence from one of its ends to the other.
I see two guards in the distance.
Dad and I spend all our time trying to keep the pub afloat, and these rich bastards can pay for the same amount of people to just stand watch over deer?
What's the damn difference between us?
Why are we deprived of our faith and killed off like animals for the amusement of others?
Is this just our lot in life? Is there nothing else for us?
As self-pity balloons within me, any sense of guilt at the proposition of theft only diminishes.
I'm not wrong. There are too many deer here.
And a single person owns all of them?
They didn't work for any of this. They didn't build this place up with their own hands.
They were simply born into a rich family and inherited this land.
There's a life out there that could be saved with only one of these deer.
Please, God, if you really are up there...
I'm sure you'll forgive the transgression I'm about to commit.
The two guards turn their back on the fenced area and begin chatting among themselves.
Is this my chance?
I lower myself to a crouch and grip the broken flask in my hand.
Then I soundlessly jump over the fence.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Hngh!
I quickly make a beeline for the herd of deer.
But as I approach, the skittish creatures run away on swift hooves.
I manage to grab a deer that lags behind by the horns with my left hand.
I hold it firm and raise the broken flask aloft.
The deer turns its beady eyes towards me.
Its dark pupils stare right at me.
Suddenly, I freeze on the spot.
The deer keeps staring at me.
I screw my eyes shut and swing the sharp, broken flask downâ€”
But something strong and unyielding catches hold of my arm.
I look up to see a brawny, bearded man holding my arm in place.
Unsurprisingly enough, I got caught.
They tie my hands behind my back and throw me in some corner to wait for their boss to come home.
The rope is so tight, I can't move my hands at all.
But even in the case I could untie it, I wouldn't be able to overpower the guards.
I suppose I have no choice but to wait for judgement.
I can only hope even nobles have some kind of empathy.
If I explain my situation, maybe...
But as I trudge through the thoughts in the bog of my mind, the main door opens.

texts.name: Guard 1
texts.text: Lord Spencer!

texts.name: Guard 2
texts.text: Welcome home, milord!

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Hola, yes. What are you doing here? Who are you?
A man in gaudy clothes steps in with a relaxed gait.
He carries himself with a leisure that feels otherworldly.
Is this...
Harold Spencer?

texts.name: Guard 1
texts.text: This scoundrel here tried to steal one of your deer, milord.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Huh? My venados? Why? You like them?

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: De todas maneras, who even are you people?
Spencer turns to the guards and tilts his head to the side.

texts.name: Guard 2
texts.text: Huh? W-We keep watch over the deer.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Okey.

texts.name: Guard 1
texts.text: We also mow the grass, yes.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Huh. Riveting.

texts.name: Guard 2
texts.text: And this thief tried to steal one of them!

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Perdonenme, but I fail to see the conexion between that and you two being here.

texts.name: Guard 1
texts.text: Uh, err, well...

texts.name: Guard 2
texts.text: W-We wanted to have your judgment on what to do with this lowlife.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Juicio? From me? Why?

texts.name: Guard 1
texts.text: Lord, I...

texts.name: Guard 2
texts.text: This is your estate, and it's your deer, milord.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Indeed. They would be my venados, yes.
Spencer sounds plain bored by all this.
The white-haired woman next to him gazes off into the distance, obviously uninterested.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Do you have any ideas? Didn't this chico slip by your guard?

texts.name: Guard 1
texts.text: H-He dared enter your sacred domain!

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Mmh...

texts.name: Guard 1
texts.text: S-So I believe an execution would be fair retribution. His head must roll!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What?!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You want to kill me?! I didn't even do anything!

texts.name: Guard 2
texts.text: You shut up!

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Mmm, okey. Let's do that, then. This chico is rather handsome, so it'll be a waste, but oh well. Off with his head.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Let's get this over with. It's been a while since I last saw blood.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: W-Wait! I came here because I was asked to deliver a script to you!

texts.name: Guard 2
texts.text: Heh, the guilty are audacious indeed.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And how do you have the right to decide to kill me on the spot?!

texts.name: Guard 1
texts.text: ...Lad, do you know who this man is?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Huh?! What?!
Spencer looks down at me.
Again, he tilts his head to the side in confusion.
Like the deer from before, his gaze feels like it pierces right through me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Listen to what I have to say! It's my life you're toying with here!

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: You have something to say? Dimelo todo, let's hear it, then.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It was wrong of me to try to steal from you, I recognize that. I'm very sorry.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: My name is William Shakespeare. Your troupe has bought my scripts before!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I came here to deliver one of them!
I try to not sound like a madman while fervently stating my case.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Troupe? Ah, yes.
Spencer glances at the woman beside him.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Is that so?
The woman just gives him a faint smile.
Then she looks down at me.
The suspicion in her gaze is clear.
The guards exchange glances.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: My father... He fell sick, and I...

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Para. Stop right there.
Spencer closes his eyes and cuts me off.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Are you truly a poeta? Sick parents, an unforgivable crime. I've heard it all a thousand times.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: There is no beauty in it.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Your face is far more bella than anything that comes out of your mouth.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But I'm telling the truâ€”

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: De ninguna manera. No way.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Rather than your sob story, I want you see your hermosa face fly off your shoulders.
I open my mouth to try and say something, but realize the noble is not seeing me at all. It's like he's looking down at dirt on his shoe.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Off with his head, ahora mismo.

texts.name: Guard 1
texts.text: Y-Yes!

texts.name: Guard 2
texts.text: U-Understood!

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: *Pant* *Pant* *Pant*

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: It's been a while since I watched someone die. Gracias, chico. Thank you for being born.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Wait! No! Stop!

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: *Pant* *Pant* *Pant* Hooh... Hooh...
There's something wrong with this man!
Is this seriously gonna be how my life ends?!
No! Please!
I don't wanna die!
Wait.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Hm? What is it, Olive?
Are you the same Shakespeare that wrote Richard III?
That's the name of a historical drama I wrote on Rob's request a while ago.
You wrote that? Truly?
I nod vigorously.
I feel like head will come loose from all the nodding before they can chop it off.
Lord Spencer.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Yes?
This one is worth keeping alive.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Porque? Why?
He's a poet that can produce the most beautiful verses the world has ever seen.
He penned The Taming of the Shrew. Isn't that right?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Y-Yes! That's me!
I wrote that on Rob's request as well.
He sold that to this Spencer guy too?

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: De verdad?! I'll have you know that I thoroughly enjoyed the antics of that drunkard Sly.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Did you base that character off someone?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Y-Yeah, I kind of run a pub. I see a lot of drunks, so he was a mixture of all of them.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: *Gasp* Wow, what a thing!
Lord Spencer, I want to take this one for myself.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Huh? You'll take this chico?

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Aren't you getting ahead of yourself, my girl?
If he joins our troupe, I'll be able to show you true stories that move the hearts of all who see them.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: True stories?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Yes.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Well, well.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: That is quite the alluring proposal.
I am of the same mind.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: All right. Do as you will, Olive. Just one thing, however.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: I don't want to hear any rumors of unbecoming behavior, entendido?
Yes.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: Chico, from now on, you are Olive's slave. Buena suerte.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I-I'm what?

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: What a shame. I wanted to see that cute head fly. It would have been hermoso.
If he makes me yawn with his verses, I assure you his head will roll in short order.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What?!

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: How maravilloso!
You can leave things to me now.

texts.name: Spencer
texts.text: All right. Buenas noches, all.
Good night, Milord.
A slave? Me?
My jaw is clenched so tight I can hear my teeth grinding together.
The woman just stands there, looking down at me.
Whether it's pity or contempt in her eyes, I can't tell.
But unlike Spencer, at least there's some emotion in them, which makes it infinitely easier to bear.
She turns her gaze to the pair of guards.
Go back to your posts. I'll take it from here.

texts.name: Guard 1
texts.text: B-But we can hardly leave you alone with this scoundrel, Lady Olivia.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Didn't you hear me?

texts.name: Guard 2
texts.text: But...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Don't make me repeat myself.
Her voice lowers to a growl, and the guards cower behind me.

texts.name: Guard 1
texts.text: Uh...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Return any belongings he had with him.
The two men are staring at one another at a complete loss, and the woman apparently named Olivia sighs in exasperation.
The guards look genuinely unsure as to what to do.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Right now.
It sounds like she's at the end of her wits.
The guards nod, gives Olivia the parchment they took from me, and leave dejectedly.
Olivia then turns back in my direction.
Her gaze is set squarely upon me.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You are the William Shakespeare, yes?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Huh?
Her gaze feels like it's piercing right through me.
I slowly nod.
She unfolds the parchment and looks at the script within.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: A Midsummer's Night Dream. Rather good title.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Thanks...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Follow me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Huh?
Still looking down at my script, she turns and begins walking at a brisk pace.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: H-Hey!
Her white hair sways behind her as she goes.
Still with my hands tied behind my back, I chase after her.
It's a typically lively night in Tenbridge.
But Olivia strides ahead with fearless purpose.
Impressively, she still has her eyes on my script.
There aren't as many people to bump into in the middle of the night, but she's still going pretty darn fast.
I can barely keep up, tired and dazed as I am.
The looks the townspeople give me as I follow her sting.
It makes sense, I suppose.
If I saw a tied up man chasing after a girl in the middle of the night, I would stare too.
At this rate I'm gonna fall over, and getting up is not gonna be fun.
I don't care if it's a long walk, but I'd like to at least not be tied up.
Then, all of a sudden, I lose sight of her.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: H-Huh?!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: This way.
I turn towards her voice.
I'm just in time to see Olivia stepping inside a huge building.
White outer walls curve before me, forming a circular building.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Whoa, this is...
Looking back down at my feet, I go in after Olivia.
And when I finally take a breath and look up again, the audience seats spread across my peripheral vision.
It's the Globe Theater.
Tenbridge's greatest theater.
Even I know the name.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Is this your first time here?
I look over at her.
She's standing in the middle of the theater, her form beautifully illuminated by the moonlight.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Uh...
Dumbfounded, I stare at her while my sluggish mind tries to come up with an answer.
Her silky white hair flutters in the breeze.
Olivia looks over the empty seats.
I follow her gaze and get a good look at the vastness of the theater. Rows upon rows of empty seats march upwards toward the sky.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I've come here to see plays before, but...
I look at the empty seats again.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's my first time seeing it empty.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Yes. It's quite silent without the people, isn't it?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Good place, isn't it?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah.
I take in the scenery and then turn to the stage.
On top of the wooden stage stands a pair of huge vermilion pillars.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: We can house over two thousand spectators when we have a full house.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Even more if we pack in as many groundlings as we can.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Just imagining the pleasure of being bathed by the ovation of such an audience puts sex to shame.
My head snaps back to her on reflex.
Her fair cheeks glow under the moonlight like polished marble.
Her attention is focused on the square.
Forgetting to speak, or even breathe, I simply stare at her profile.
Something in her enraptured expression captivates me. It feels like I'm being pulled in by a force majeure.
How can there exist such a beautiful woman?
Without warning, she turns back to me, and our gazes clash.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'm buying you.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...Excuse me?
Buying me? Like a pet?
Or...
Like a slave?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'll keep you as my slave.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: A slave.
So both, really.
She's buying and enslaving me like an animal.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You'll write.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: For my troupe only.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Stories that will set Tenbridge's very heart ablaze and crush the paradigms with your prose.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You, and only you, can do this.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Wait a minute now...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: If you want to keep your head over your shoulders, you have no choice.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Write or die.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Your choice.
Her tone is neutral and monotonous. She stares at me, her mouth set into a hard line.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: So...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: If I write, I get to stay alive?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You won't be suffered to live a second more if you don't.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Did I even have a choice to begin with?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I suppose not.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: First, you'll fix this.
Olivia then pushes the script of A Midsummer Night's Dream onto me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Fix what?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: It needs more characters and more scenes. It's written well, but people will ask for their money back if it's this short a play.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But Iâ€”

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: They won't be able to judge whether it's good or not if the fun is over when it's barely started. Our main visitors are the common folk.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'll wait until tomorrow for you to fix it. Write something bad and it's all over for you.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Swear it, right here and now.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Swear to me that you will never write stale verses.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...Okay, I'll fix this. I'll do what I can.

texts.name: Olivia
